awd_titl_txt: Developing Pulsed Power Driven Turbulent Reconnection Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop a new experimental platforms for studying magnetic reconnection in a magnetized plasma, a  gas of electrically charged particles permeated by magnetic fields.  The Earth can be thought of as a spacecraft surrounded by the solar wind, a swirling sea of hot plasma ejected from the Sun.  The Earth's magnetic field usually protects us from this solar wind, but intense solar storms can break through and cause significant damage to the orbiting satellites used for communication and navigation, and potentially even damage power grids and other infrastructure on the Earth's surface. Predicting these damaging solar storms is an ongoing challenge, and involves a detailed understanding of a process called magnetic reconnection, which enables these storms to explosively erupt from the Sun's surface.  Better understanding of magnetic reconnection using new dedicated laboratory experiments supported by this award will improve our ability to model and forecast these damaging storms.

Magnetic reconnection and turbulence are fundamentally linked processes - instabilities in the reconnection layer drive a turbulent cascade, and this turbulence in turn efficiently drives reconnection at smaller and smaller scales. Studying turbulent reconnection layers in the laboratory is an outstanding challenge, requiring hot plasmas to be created and sustained, as well as new diagnostics to resolve a wide range of spatial scales. This award will use a new pulsed-power driven experimental platform to study different methods of producing a turbulent reconnection layer, with the goal of understanding how turbulence enhances the reconnection rate with applications to astrophysical plasmas as well as novel fusion experiments using magnetized high-energy-density plasmas. A successful platform will enable access to a unique regime of magnetized plasma turbulence, offering insight into important open questions in modern theories of plasma turbulence: the existence of critical balance, the transition from the magnetohydrodynamic to kinetic regime at small length scales, and the uneven partition of energy between the electrons and ions.  This award is made with support from the National Nuclear Security Administration within the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied magnetic reconnection in the laboratory. Magnetic reconnection is a process in plasmas which breaks apart and reforms magnetic field lines. Reconnection is responsible for Coronal Mass Ejections, in which a large blob of plasma twists the magnetic fields which confine it until the fields break and reconnect, freeing the plasma. This plasma then erupts out into the solar system, and if it collides with the Earth, it can cause significant damage to satellites and to terrestrial power grids. Hence, understanding how reconnection occurs may enable us to more accurately forecast these potentially damaging events.

In the laboratory, we studied reconnection by using intense pulses of electrical current to heat thin wires to the plasma state. The large currents and magnetic fields accelerated the plasma, bringing oppositely directed magnetic field lines together and driving magnetic reconnection. We studied reconnection in a new plasma regime, in which the constituent particles of the plasma, ions and electrons, move somewhat independently, creating complex structures. These structures are particularly interesting because scientists also study reconnection by flying satellites through plasma in space---these satellites only see their local environment, so recreating the global environment in the laboratory helps us to understand these satellite observations of reconnection.

This research carried out primarily by graduate student Thomas Varnish, along with three other graduate students at MIT, who helped with the experiments and with running computer simulations to understand the experimental observations. The research also included three under-graduate students at MIT who helped with the development of the magnetic probes used in the experiments. The experiments were carried out at the MAIZE pulsed-power facility at the University of Michigan Ann Arbor, and involved graduate students and post-doctoral researchers there.

In addition, this project supported the construction of PUFFIN (The PUlser For Fundamental Investigations), a new pulsed-power facility at MIT. PUFFIN will be used for further magnetic reconnection experiments, as well as for studying other fundamental physics processes such as magnetized turbulence and magneto-hydrodynamic shocks. PUFFIN will be relocated to Cornell University in the Summer of 2025.
